multiple_choice_question.text: This formula describes the contrast of spectral features in **transit spectroscopy**, which depends on the altitude difference probed (∆z). Which of the following statements about this formula is **incorrect**?
choices: The contrast of spectral features is directly proportional to the altitude difference probed (∆z).
The contrast of spectral features is inversely proportional to the square of the stellar radius (R<sub>s</sub>).
This formula assumes the altitude range probed is significantly larger than the atmospheric scale height.
The contrast of spectral features is larger for cooler host stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula estimates the planet-to-star flux ratio (F<sub>p</sub>/F<sub>s</sub>) for **high contrast imaging** using reflected light. What does the variable Φ(90°) represent in this equation?
choices: The geometric albedo of the exoplanet.
The phase function of the exoplanet at quadrature (phase angle of 90°).
The ratio of planetary radius (R<sub>p</sub>) to orbital distance (a).
The effective temperature of the host star.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts the apparent albedo spectrum of Earth at different phases. What causes the significant increase in reflectivity towards shorter wavelengths in the crescent phase spectrum **with glint** (black curve) compared to the crescent phase spectrum **without glint** (grey curve)?
choices: Rayleigh scattering in Earth\'s atmosphere.
Specular reflection of sunlight from the ocean surface (glint).
Thermal emission from Earth\'s surface.
Absorption by water vapor in Earth\'s atmosphere.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure showcases the reflectivity spectra of hypothetical Earth-like planets with varying atmospheric temperatures and pressures. Which statement is **supported** by the trends observed in these spectra?
choices: Increasing surface pressure leads to a steeper Rayleigh scattering slope and deeper absorption bands.
Decreasing surface temperature leads to wider and shallower absorption bands.
Changes in atmospheric pressure have a negligible effect on the Rayleigh scattering slope.
Atmospheric temperature is the primary factor influencing the depths of absorption bands.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates the integration time required to achieve a specific signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for direct imaging of Earth twins in the V-band. What is the **primary limitation** to achieving high SNR observations for mapping Pale Blue Dots at large distances (>10 pc)?
choices: The faintness of the exoplanet signal compared to the host star.
The need for extremely large diameter telescopes.
The long integration times required, potentially exceeding several hours.
The limited availability of suitable target stars at such distances.
